title: Are smart people attracted to smart people? - Quora

response.answer_text: As has been pointed out, if you’re a smart person you’ll only be compatible with other people roughly as smart as you. But compatibility is not attraction. I don’t think that smart people in general are attracted to other smart people because of their intelligence. It’s an important box to check off when you do the compatibility assessment, but for many smart people, I don’t think it’s sexy. There is, however, a personality trait that correlates reasonably well with intelligence, in that most of the people with the trait are smart or very smart (but the opposite is not true; it’s not that common a trait). And if you have that trait, it’s definitely sexy when someone else shares it. I call that trait eucognition, the trait of liking to think, of being more interested in the “life of the mind” than in “activities.” [1] Most people’s hobbies include the likes of travel, sports and recreation, dining, dancing, video gaming, partying, socializing. A lot of very smart people spend their weekends doing these things. Sitting around with their friends and analyzing stuff as a fun weekend activity? Seriously? However, there are people whose idea of the best possible time is to get together with a small group of friends and (for instance) watch a really good movie, and then talk about it for 90 minutes or two hours. And those 90 - 120 minutes typically consist of 30 minutes about the movie itself, with the rest of the time devoted to tangents inspired by the conversation. Personal stories get told and connected to the movie’s themes (or not!) and to each other. Insightful connections are made. [2] People like that are definitely attracted to other people like that. We get pleasure from hearing and considering a cool, new idea, exactly like a foodie gets pleasure from a new dish or a skier gets pleasure from a great run down the mountain. And why are we attracted to someone? Because we can imagine engaging with them pleasurably. My memorable first meetings with women have admittedly all begun with physical attraction. But I’ve struck up many conversations with women I’ve found attractive, and the handful that led to something more were the ones where the conversations were electrifying in their intellectual sparks and rapport. [1] I think this is the single personality trait that most determines who you associate with, and the reason it’s gone fundamentally unrecognized is that people tend to only associate with others like themselves. It’s the fundamental “geek” trait if we define “geek” as someone who enjoys knowledge for its own sake. It’s ubiquitous in science fiction fandom and widespread in other similar subcultures. [3] [2] This is in fact a description of what my friends and I have done once a week for the past 14 years, with the secret being that the movies are interlaced with watching complete runs of brilliant, thought-provoking TV series, beginning with Buffy the Vampire Slayer. Several members of the “Buffy Gang” will upvote this! [3] [3] Yes, Quora is a community with a high incidence of eucognition.

I would assume that many are. That’s what I’ve observed at least …..by peeping at everyone through my binoculars up here in the tree… But even as an idiot, I’m attracted to smart people as well. As long as they’re not too arrogant about their superior intellect, I almost always find it refreshing to speak with people who are one step ahead of me (or 30) who just know what I mean or even what I’m about to say. It’s comforting and comfortable. You feel understood and in good hands. But really, I think people are generally attracted to people who are either smarter than themselves or somewhere near their own level. People like those they can relate to in some way, and I think exceptionally few people are attracted to or have much interest in people they perceive to be beneath them. So rather than strictly being a question of whether intelligence is attractive to other attractive people, I think it has a lot to do with social status as well. I mean, there are plenty of intelligent people who’ve fallen on hard times and are now homeless. And how many intelligent people would openly admit an attraction for them? They might if the “dirty hobo” somehow miraculously pulls himself up and makes a change, but an intelligent bum on the street is still a bum to most. Personally, I care most about personality and compatibility of the minds. I can overlook a scruffy face or a bad attitude as long as there’s a connection and the conversation keeps flowing. And because it’s so difficult to have a conversation with someone who cannot understand you, I’m instinctively drawn to people who are as smart or smarter than myself. I hate repeating myself and explaining everything I say. And with the right person, there’s no need for any of that. And that’s why I’d much rather date, say, a nerdy or bookish librarian than the hottest social media bimbo everyone keeps lusting after. The bimbo may be able to give me a “good time”. But the librarian could give my life meaning.

Being attracted to smart people is an orientation known as sapiosexual. While I have done a lot of studying on the topics of sex and relationships, the extent to which being smart and being sapiosexual may correlate is beyond my expertise. You’d have to look up the scientific studies that have been done on the subject if you hope to obtain any definitive insight therein. Therefore, I can only offer an anecdotal response. To clarify, I would consider myself to be sapiosexual and I’m confident that any objective analysis of the totality of evidence would reasonably categorize me as “smart” in the conventional sense. Or in the academic sense at least. Let’s not get into a debate about the narrow scope of what is considered intelligence and what is not in our modern western academic system. I do consider intelligence to be an attractive trait. Let’s not mince words here: by “attractive” I mean I find it sexy. And not just general intelligence. I’m drawn to people who exhibit excellence in just about any one skill, including artistic and athletic pursuits. Because it doesn’t seem to be a common viewpoint, I should note here that I consider aptitude in creative and physical fields to be forms of intelligence. Paint amazing portraits? That’s hot. World champion cyclist? Marry me. Can you build a ten foot cairn? I’m done for. Quick wit? Smitten. To be sure, I also find my preferred sex to be physically attractive in the same conventional sense that most people seem to do. I just don't take an interest beyond the casual thought of “huh… she’s pretty” unless there’s also an indication of intelligence in general or aptitude in a specific area. Also, those signals usually override any sense of conventional attractiveness, in my experience. Now, I don’t like this business of ranking people on a ten point scale one bit, but for the purposes of illustration: say you stood an impeccably dressed 5 next to a 9 dressed in a phoned-in outfit. I’m most likely to be drawn to the average girl with a sense of style over the uncoordinated hottie. I won’t dismiss the idea that a better-dressed woman probably looks more attractive than a worse-dressed person, but putting together a cute outfit is something I consider to take a bit of creativity and some brainpower, so if I’m impressed with your attire, then I’m impressed with you, and I pretty much have to be impressed in some way in order to be attracted. And that’s the thing about conventional physical attractiveness - it doesn’t impress me much. You don’t have to do anything to be born hot. How much all this is because of how smart I may or may not be is a mystery to me. It doesn’t seem to me like being attracted to intelligence or any form of excellence should be limited to the more intelligent among us. And I’m sure there are plenty of brainiacs who are well satisfied with chasing airheaded hotties, to put it crudely.

I'll say my experience as someone with an IQ of 164, not at all. I am attracted to people not based on their intelligence, I have never met a woman with my same IQ or higher but I have met women with IQs in the 150s. The trait is not attractive one bit, it helps though since having some traits without a good IQ can make you unattractive to me. Overall I do not see that much difference between somebody with an IQ of 90 and an IQ of 140 while doing things I enjoy as part of a couple, but some people with IQs like me lead a scholarly life and enjoy a completely different type of activities than me, if that is the life you lead and the interests you carry I can see how it might hurt a relationship. There is also another factor playing a role here that is I believe more important, although Freud was insane with some of his theories I do believe that our parents play a role in what we grow up to look for in a partner, if you take that into account and the fact that IQ is statistically speaking mostly hereditary there will surely be a tendency in the form of a correlation to find attractive people with higher IQs. I'm an oddball in that my parents are not nearly as smart as I am, my mother is smart but she is no genius by my standards and my father is not even that, he is simply average. To quote Barry White: “I don't want clever conversations… Don't want to work that hard… I just want some-someone to talk to.” To me friendship requires an higher floor than love to the IQ of a person, I am perfectly happy just taking a stroll on the beach or watching the sunset with the woman I love without saying a word or talking about the scenery while with a friend if he starts telling me how cute is that cloud that looks like a bunny I wonder if I should take away his drink. xD Also, with friends I am only interested in what we can do and if you don't need my help I couldn't care less about your life which cuts down a whole avenue of conversation that I find wholly fascinating in a woman. The brother of one of my exes had an IQ similar to mine and he was perfectly happy in a 8 year relationship with a woman that his whole family considered dumb and not one bit of a match. He just like me didn't have genius parents. So I believe it isn't simply that smart people are attracted to smart people, simply people look mostly unknowingly for traits found in their parents in a potential partner. Of course I am talking specifically about IQs 160+ perhaps for us the scarcity leads us to make this adjustment, actually in my experience this might very well be the case because I was often told by people with IQs in the 130-150 range how they could never date X because they “couldn't talk with them” which I personally think is a self-important load of crap and more often than not they didn't have any problems with an equally gifted person as long as she/he had less dissonating ideas on polarizing topics. The problem wasn't not being smart but simply making bad arguments mostly about politics coming from their political opposition. On the other hand I have never met anybody with an IQ above 160 with the same problem but that is entirely anecdotal.

This question is really interesting for me as I have been wondering that. First, you have got to know I have never been into a relationship before and I can count with one hand all the times I have been attracted by a guy. Since my childhood, I would be often told I am very smart for my young age. Even now, I am actually 16. People cannot help but notice how my way of thinking is very at miles away from other children's. It's kind of them to say this though I feel like I would better be called things like gregarious, coward, sad, happy. I mean real adjectives which would describe my personality. This is why I have a huge interest somehow for people who are not very smart. I know it may seem like nonsense, but I admire their carefree way of living, their self confidence like nothing bad could ever happen. When I am around them, I feel like I am around people with whom Life is going to be much funnier than alone myself. Even though we do not share the same interests, I love experiencing new things for the sake of knowledge. With them, I can leave the thinking and take the step. In addition, I think Life is about complementarity. As Humans, we have to complete each other with our inner capacities and personality. With less smart people, I can be of real use. Nevertheless, I have to admit that I often feel attracted to smarter people with whom I can have very deep and intense conversations. By attracted, I think we agree on “attracted in general, not romantically". As I said above, I love learning new things. With smart, even smarter people, I can deepen my thoughts and the universe inside me... Beside, Smart people seem soooo cool, collected whatever the situation is or however it gets. It gives me a feeling of inner security. All my friends are smart people in fact, but I also like to simply chat with less smart people. We laugh a lot. I also it comes from my INFJ nature. Maybe it really depends on the every smart people personality. Who knows ? Well, I am attracted by both people in general as with the two of them, we can either get deep and intense experiences or funny ones

Intelligence is a curse in a relationship.More important is the caring and consideration for each other. Relationships are not based on IQ. Never were and never will be. For convenience maybe if you are in a high profile position and need a partner for public display and appearance. For a relationship to work it just needs two people who care about each other and want to take care of each other. If IQ was the criteria then the really smart people would never have a Wife/Husband/Same Sex Partner.After all if it were not for sex then these partnerships/marriages would not be needed and we all know sex does not require intelligence. This is just not true. What is the definition of a meaningful relationship?The suggestion IQ/Intelligence is the key is ridiculous. The fact is men and women get together because they can offer many things for each other.Comfort, sex, companionship, caring, enjoying life together and so much more. “Meaningful relationship and high intelligence” I think we need to discuss tonights menu for the bedroom. Do you have time for this now? Last time it failed to meet my expectations since you were unable to sustain your performance long enough for me to be satisfied. How do you propose we correct this flaw in your abilities?” “Well you are correct, However I did achieve my goal of satisfaction so there was a high degree of success there. If we consider you did receive some stimulation and degree of excitement then the success rate you could say was well above 50% and most likely between 75–80%. That is a great outcome in anyone’s books” “I accept your argument, however, at our level of intellect we should be capable of achieving close to 100% success with both parties achieving total satisfaction at the end of the passionate session.” “I believe you are correct. Since we are so intelligent we can work this out easily. Don’t you agree?” “Of course I do now what can you do to sustain your performance until I am fully satisfied?” “Perhaps some research is in order to establish suitable performance methods intended to achieve your desired outcome of satisfaction for both.” “Yes I agree. Lets do some research to see what options we have.” Girl with less intelligence (IQ below the range of this couple)“Lets go to bed and have some fun”. “Great Idea”.“I so much enjoyed our love making, How about you.” “Yes. Did I satisfy you. I was ok. Can we do it again.”“I just love you being with me. It makes me so happy” “Me too” I cant wait to come home and be in your arms again every day.“Did you see the news today. Never mind we can look at that later. Come here and give me a kiss and cuddle.”“did you like the meal I cooked or Did you like dinner I brought home for you?“Yes it was my favourite. Thanks (Much value placed on remembering and recognising what pleases the partner (two way street of course)” Intelligence does not make for a good relationship at all. It creates people who are analytical and judgmental with High Expectations. This is a failure waiting to happen. There are so many examples of successful relationships where one is a doctor/Professional/CEO/Wealthy Businessman/woman and the other a good looking not so intelligent girl/guy. Society and research is limited to small samples and not reliable. Any research with a limited number of people cannot be trusted to present reality. Evidence shows that in excess of 70% of Australian Filipino marriages are successful. This in itself proves the research wrong.

They might. But if I am allowed to elaborate the answer, keeping one attracted is a whole different set of discussion. Let's equalize being smart here to high IQ. I have met numerous of them in my life. Now let's take a sample. There's a married couple with their academics being bright. For sure, when getting to know the first time, their intelligence was what attracted each other. Days and nights they couldn't stop getting impressed on how lucky they were to find each other “what a genius. Now this is what I call the new sexy. Unlike those with “only” physical attraction. Boring, low quality.” No, I am not saying they were wrong to standardize their qualification of a partner through smartness, because that thing is attractive. Who can easily stop talking when there's a person to talk with about anything? About the universe? About unlimited ideas? We feel like finally there's a person understanding our ideas, while in normal days “boring” people can't really grasp our subjects, right? But here's the wrong. As much as they love the intelligence feature displayed by one and another, they mostly relied their judgement to live in the future as a married couple with mainly the same thing, each other's intelligence. Now that's not a so smart move. Look, intelligence, cognitive virtue, skill set to develop ideas/inventions, ain't the same as daily skill set. Let's call it that. Realistically speaking, we live in society. We don't live with ourselves, no matter how much we think we can. At one point we must meet someone to interact with and it requires more than intelligence to preserve ourselves in society. Intelligence alone is not enough. One can be intelligent and a jerk at the same time and no matter how the world still admires intelligence, such a person would get marginalized overtime for being considered unable to uplift moral standard. They would be placed only in a spot where they are good at (job, for example), but in other life aspects no one really voluntarily wills to get close to them. “A smart jerk? Why letting ourselves getting dragged into a dark pit?”. Intelligence is great and special, okay. But comfort can't lie. As much as infidelity is totally wrong, undeniably a lot of times their reason to cheat is because they feel comfortable with their affair partner. Everyone takes intelligent people special but the craving for comfort in heart is never a lie. Who can't stand talking to a smart person who is hard to deal and compromise with and it makes them sound hypocrite much or less, everyday? Man, I condemn infidelity, not in campaign for it. But living with such a “smart” partner doesn't mean it won't suffocate you. At one point, the person you are much attracted to for their smartness could be the very same person you feel sick about, gradually listening to their unshaky uncompromised intelligence while we know life isn't about relying only on IQ. On the other note, no matter how much someone feels about their partner, do not cheat. Solve the problem. If leave is the last resort, do it with honesty and dignity only after an adequate discussion conducted. Cheating is cheating and it's wrong no matter how badly you justify it. Learn to grow up and do things with dignity and honor. Now back to that couple. After knowing each other for several years, now they're on the way to divorce in less than a year of marriage. Turned out the admired partner was not so morally advance. Using the intelligence to manipulate the other, thinking the other person wouldn't realize it. Forgetting that the other person was also intelligent, one can't just get away with their manipulation. When someone is intelligent at the same time acquiring good moral, it's hard to continue the relationship with a partner who only exhibits intelligence with 0 moral. The intelligence would get ashy overtime. Good moral is always few steps ahead. Kindness brings warmth to the heart. Everyone wants to come home and hug/get hugged by someone with warmness. In relationships it's often enough to deal with intelligence only at works. When they are home they want someone to lean on who can do daily basis together as partners. Someone they can trust, whom they don't have to worry about cheating when they leave the partner alone. In fact, most of the times after a failed relationship, the very same people now want a more 'simple’ partner “no need to be crazily wealthy, genius, model-looking. Now as long as he/she is faithful, that's enough. I got it what I need in life.” So yes a smart person could be attracted to other smart person. But it would just be temporary if they only rely on the intelligence in order to preserve the attraction. There are values and most of them are moral ones when coming to any relationship.

Yup. I am answering as a member of Intertel (99%) & Mensa (98%). Before I met my wife, I dated young women with no regard to intellect… and that was an issue. While these girls were sweet and attractive, to me they were just… dumb. At times, I felt more like a parent than a boyfriend. When I met my wife, her job title was Vice President of a biotech startup firm. Aside from her magnetic eyes, this really caught my attention. As we got to know each other, I was continually impressed with her capability to pull conclusions out of seemingly disparate data points and arrive at very accurate, logical conclusions. Opposite of feeling like her parent/educator, I realized I could learn from her and we could figure out the world together. I fell in love with her very quickly; I had her ring 6 months from our first meeting. My wife is nothing short of amazing and I recognize what a lucky man I am. Oh, and she's gorgeous to boot.  Edit 01/15/2020: WOW! So many upvotes and views! I am humbled :-) Also, I have been asked about her Myers-Briggs personality type… my wife is an INTJ Architect, which presents in less than 1% of the female population and is strongly correlated with the highest intelligence levels. Interestingly, I am also an INTJ Architect. So… she is truly a catch, indeed!

I think all the negative, sarcastic commenters are getting this totally wrong. Being “gifted” (in quotation marks because I hate that expression) is more similar to being autistic or just being “on a different frequency” than the remaining 98% of the population than it is being an otherwise normal human with ~Superior Extra Intelligence~. Therefore, as children, “gifted” people often have a hard time making friends because we don’t “get” normal kids and they certainly don’t “get” us. This does get less prominent as we get older, but most “gifted” people will still feel this odd sense of being a little “off” with people in general. I have most of my experience with platonic friendships. I guess I percieve platonic companionship as a basic necessity and romantic relationships as a luxury, and I struggled with feeling very lonely and distanced for the first 12–13 years of my life. Then I transferred schools to the only school for gifted children here in the small country of Denmark and I formed the strong, deep bonds to the 3–4 people I still consider my closest friends today, 7 years later. I have a radar similar to the “gaydar” some people claim to have. I can just sense immediately if someone is gifted too. It’s in their humor, their observations, their remarks, sometimes I can see it in people’s eyes - it’s like we’re on a different plane of consciousness, for better or for worse. You can’t become gifted no matter how hard you try, just like you can’t become autistic. And trust me, you shouldn’t want to. You are fine as you are. I grew up in a suburb and I believe it’s easier for gifted people to make friends and fall in love in big cities, simply because they are more densely populated and have a statistically higher chance of running into other gifted people. I am in the highest 2% of the population IQ-wise and take my word: it does NOT mean I’m wiser or better at studying or any of those cliché-film-traits of a gifted person. I overthink everything to a disabling extent, I can’t function in the traditional academic education system, and my emotional coping abilities are immature. I’m hypersensitive and have ADD traits. I perceive the world fundamentally different. But I’m, like, really good at language-related skills, writing and coming up with language-based jokes. :p

Some will, but I dated girls of both average and very high intelligence. My fiancé was the smartest girl in her school. She cheated on me so I left her. Then I met my wife, a graduate of a trade school. She was so sweet and kind. I fell in love with her immediately and we were engaged 2 weeks later. We are married over 47 years and it has been a great marriage. She keeps asking why I married her. It was for her soul. She genuinely wants to please people. She does not have a mean bone in her body. She takes good care of me. She held down the homestead when I was away on business over 12 weeks in a year. She put up with 13 relocations and decorating 9 houses we owned. My nephew married an intelligent girl with a Masters Degree. He has a BS in computer science and yet he quits his job to move whoever his wife takes a new job. He cooks and cleans plus takes care of the kids while holding down a full time job. The girl that my wife and I shared for 30 years married a doctor. She feels that housework is beneath her so they have a housekeeper and eat out or have food delivered every day. When she stayed with us for a week or weekend, she does not know how to make a cup of coffee, cook or work a washing machine. My wife had to do all of that for her. Her husband got stuck raising her kid from a previous marriage and never had a home cooked meal from her. Say what you will, I am much happier with my wife who genuinely enjoys being the mistress of our home, and is nothing like me. Two of me would not get along well at all.

Smart people are attracted to interesting people regardless of their intelligence. Of course that includes many smart people, and that makes my answer partially, “Yes.” For serious relationships I prefer women who are in my intelligence range and who are sufficiently accomplished that I can learn many things from them and enjoy talking and even arguing with them. I did have a negative experience with certifiably intelligent women. Many years ago I used my SAT scores to join Mensa with the goal of meeting intelligent women to date. Unfortunately for me, the local chapter of Mensa had some really nice and interesting women, but they were all married. The single women in that chapter and at that time were not people I enjoyed being around for long. Likely, they felt the same about me. I have since met many highly intelligent single women who are unusually good and interesting people, but high intelligence does not guarantee this. Isaac Newton is an example of a really intelligent person that few people of any intelligence would want to be around or could be attracted to. Of course his tragic childhood contributed to this, but he still wasn’t an attractive person. While intelligence is an important factor for me personally in forming long term romantic relationships, it isn’t much of a factor in my formation of other friendships.

I never thought i will be answering this - I have dated few women in life. Mostly i felt unfulfilled and something missing almost always. And then i met this amazing women. She had a different outlook to life. She saw the world completely differently from what I did. She talked about her work and aspirations so passionately it would give me shivers. She would have logical strong opinions about things, and she would voice and argue about them, most of the times peacing out on no one is right. She would talk about changing the world, have plans about it. We would discuss the world and how things work, and how mountains look at night and how the sunrises are the best times of the day. She would make me feel do more in life, constantly. She makes me learn new things. She inspires me to read up new things about her work and her opinions. She would make me meet her friends, and i would be amazed to see such amazing people. and THEN she would have childish worries, that make her the cutest kid i have known. She is beautiful on top of it. She makes me feel excited about life, makes me look forward to meet her. I dont know if this is categorised as being smart. I dont even consider myself smart. But yes, i have never felt so fulfilled with anyone else. TAKE HOME MESSAGE - its really not about smart people attracting smart people. I am attracted to women who have an opinion about almost everything, can express it, work it up with logic, and argue if she feels i contest her thoughts. At the same time, she makes you feel loved and respected. It’s a beautiful feeling to feel challenged and loved at the same time. It keeps my life alive. Love her to MACS0647-JD and beyond.

Of course! Smart people are attracted to smart people (like everyone else) because they learn stuff from smart people — usually things worth knowing. Being smart yourself means that you know that you don’t know everything and can learn from others. It’s a pleasure to hear even what you do know, expressed by persons you consider “smart”. They probably have the same or similar backgrounds. In addition, there is a certain comfort in being around people who look and act like you. On the one hand it’s likely that intellectually, you share similar tastes and dislikes and can communicate them on the same level. On the other hand, you can feel safe from idiots; you will have others on your side if confronted by lesser individuals.

Yes… based on Leta Hollingsworths work they sort of have to be. The study concluded with the fact that you can only form meaningful relations to people within 30 IQ points of your own. This after that suggests that considering that the higher IQ you've got the less possibility there was to meet up someone within that restriction, then it becomes harder to get somebody to love the smarter you will be. So yes, wise folks are drawn to smart people simply because they wouldn’t survive a “average” companion. Imagine it if you(Presuming you may be normal) continued a romantic date with some body of a 70 IQ… you'lln’t want it if you do not have some perverted caretaker fetish;)  ;)

Disclosure of my personal abilities: To put this into perspective, I am no genius, but, I am somewhat intelligent. My IQ is estimated to be about 111 (tested) so I’m within the average intelligence, and only a touch above. Furthermore, I have a pretty extensive education (I understand knowledge and intelligence are not the same, but both are essential to be in the realm of an intellectual. My education is a decent college and I’m halfway through my BBA. So far I’m exceeding in my education. my personal opinion. Being intelligent to me isn’t a primary factor in who I become attractive to, but unintelligent people think below 80 IQ will raise my eyebrows. What really gets me is a person’s knowledge, people that don’t have the most basic knowledge or even interest in topics like biology, history, philosophy, the basic principles of economy or business. I just find these people lacking of substance, since then I’m forced to find other topics of interest, that often have less to talk about. If “shopping” and “Netflix” are on a girls tinder profile I’m less interested than if they put nothing at all in their bio. I value someone with the mental strength and knowledge to add value I can’t attain with my perspective. So to sum it up for a person like me, exceptionally low intelligence is a turn off but not a deal breaker. Intelligence is largely unchangeable, at least in the sense that one can’t add 50 points to their IQ at will. A lack of knowledge is a dealbreaker since I don’t really gain new experiences or ideas from people lacking a desire for knowledge. This is a bigger deal for me since anyone can learn.

Yes… based on Leta Hollingsworths work they sort of have to be. The study concluded with the fact that you can only form meaningful relations to people within 30 IQ points of your own. This then indicates that because the higher IQ you have the less chance there is to meet someone within that limit, then it becomes harder to find a partner to love the smarter you are. So yes, smart people are attracted to smart people because they wouldn’t survive a “average” partner. Imagine it if you(Presuming you are average) went on a date with someone of a 70 IQ… You wouldn’t like it unless you have some kinky caretaker fetish;)  ;)

Note that in answering this question I am apparently calling myself “smart”. I debated whether I should even try to answer this question because of that classification. But the question fascinates me, so here I go… I have been a lot of places, I have known a lot of people. I have written professionally, I have produced TV programs, I have been a line cook and I once, briefly, worked in a fish-packing plant. So if I am not smart, I am at least experienced. I still believe what a poet might believe, that attraction — and by extension “love” — can’t really be quantified in limited terms. Science will one day understand all there is to know about attraction, a day long from now, but at this time, no. I appreciate the long, thoughtful responses to this question, but in the end, attraction happens or it doesn’t and nobody knows the hell why. Enjoy attraction if it’s reciprocated and don’t think about it too much. Life is too short. p.s. I can’t be too smart…I had to look up the proper spelling of “reciprocated”.

I think so. I don’t like to talk too much about my IQ because doing so is considered a bit pretentious where I come from, but yes, I wanted — and found — a wife with whom I’m able to have in-depth conversations about things that I know about. I’m talking about marriage here, but the same is true to some extent of any relationship : communicating with somebody whose IQ is much lower than one’s own requires a lot of dumbing down and leaves the person with the higher IQ feeling very lonely, with the person they are trying to relate to being unable to understand them in any meaningful way (and the person with the lower IQ, for his or her part, feels that the other party is talking over their head all the time). I got lucky, and married an incredibly intelligent woman whose father considered anything below 130 to be “low IQ”. I’d be hard-put to name a single member of her family whose IQ appears to be below that, so I think I made a prize catch. And oh yes, it’s our silver anniversary this coming November.

Smart people understand that being “smart” is not a static, unchanging mental condition — like an IQ number. To remain smart, one must continue to learn new stuff (as the world changes) and update the old stuff as what you know becomes obsolete. It’s been estimated that half of what a new college graduate learns, becomes functionally out-of-date within a decade — faster in STEM fields. How do smart people stay smart? One way is by cavorting with other smart people! Smart people are attracted to other smart people to gauge their “smartness” by how well they engage with others, especially other smart people. They are reaffirmed if other smart people want to be around them but, they also understand that they can learn valuable lessons from not-so-smart people as well. (Some smart people may seek to belittle others to boost their fragile egos, but by-in-large these are not really smart people.) Bottom line: one becomes smarter by being around smart people (and likewise dumber by being around dumb people).

Study of sapiosexuality suggests some people really are sexually attracted to intelligence. The study in the journal Intelligence found that most people desire a partner who is smart. (Here is an example of smart and pretty(Natalie is super intelligent) Intelligence is a attracted, there is nothing to do with the fact that 2 people are intelligence besides the face that they can challenge each other. However, If we want to know if and how many people there are for whom intelligence is literally physically arousing and not just attractive in a potential partner they are already physically attracted to, then this should be possible to study in terms of physiological responses instead of self-reporting in a vacuum. Quora is OBSESSED with IQ questions. Sometimes I think the questions are suggested in a gently trolling way to make those IQ elitists reply and look like the maladjusted people they really are to everyone else. I have an above average IQ. Between 120–130 according to childhood tests, not that I think that is indicative of my current IQ or that I particuarly believe in IQ tests in general. I am a professional software engineer. My wife has an average IQ of 100. She is a cleaner. She has had a very difficult life and has lots of interesting insights into life and I would say that she acquired wisdom through this difficult life. She is also very creative and an artist. Does any of this matter? No. What matters a bit is that we both have reasonbly high EQ (Emotional Intelligence) and so we are able to talk about any problems that come up. The most important thing though is that we are compatible with each other and we care and love each other a lot. That is all you need.

I'm on the smart side, I don't like bragging IQ, but i have a PhD in physics and a very curious personality. I'll go against some other answers and say that intelligence don't matter much when we're talking attraction. There was this interesting study (I lost the title sorry) where they were looking at correlation between who's having sex for each sex and associated traits. Successful women had either high hips to waist ratio, younthful appearance or neoteny (cuteness). Successful men mostly had high socio economical status (which intelligence can be a part of). I dated some very smart and some very simple girls and i can't say it made much difference to me. I ended up marrying a very sweet, caring and cute girl (neoteny FTW). She also has a high hips to waist ratio so jackpot haha. She didn't go to university, but still has an interesting point of view and we have interesting conversations everyday.

Are smart people attracted to smart people? Yes, but intelligence is not the only factor. As others in this thread have said, discussions with intellectuals can easily turn into an ego-inflated game of who is the authority on a given topic. This kind of people seriously turn me off. I don’t thrive on heated debates. I thus prefer dating women of average intelligence who love me and who respect me just the way I am.

Oh yes! Very well yes! Of course yes! You feel you’ve got one thing Otherwise it is quite the routine boring conversations! Time doesn’t seem to work Adoration is quite A door to expression Voice chats are beyond Void Ice! Days run like minutes and are highly meaningful!

It depends on the definition of attracted. I will assume unlike other posters that you mean sexual attraction for the purposes of mating. Assortive mating for intelligence is higher than for any other human characteristic. So yes, smart people tend to be attracted to smart people. Most of that has to do with sociocultural pressures to ensure offspring success in an ever more complex world. Things change and epigenetics will drive changes in mating strategies which could emphasize other traits, like height, and strength.

I might not be the brightest light in the street but I am always lit up. My wife is the brightest light in any street. Our attraction to each other was instantaneous and lasting 20 years so far. Why? We both have a flair for accepting challenges. We also are not afraid to disagree and have arguments about those disagreements. She is politically almost far left and I am not quite as close. She has been a political activist. I have been a sporting activist. She has 4 degrees and a Ph.D. I just have a diploma and lots of sporting accreditations. She was born upper middle class. I come from poor white trash. Why do we click? Love. Simple as that. Why are we together? We both love a challenge.

I think smart people are attracted to other smart people. Based on my personal experience, I married my wife after a few relationships with women less smarter than me. My wife was smart to marry me and I was smart to marry her.. I still think she is way smarter than me especially with her engineering & computer technology background.

Although, I make every attempt to associate with all types of people to get a broader perspective on many given situations inclusive of my own life experiences even though, I’m pretty smart with or without a text book and yet, the crazies follow me close. So, I don’t know whether I’m more insane than just the average Joe? I suspect, my INFJ temperament is appealing to those who don’t harbor this attribute.

Yes, to brag knowing one beyond your limits… stealing self esteem. The match is not so much to IQ but to people exercising similar relations with the brain talking their knowledge. Smart people tend to make smart decisions, and after they learn from history they tend to learn to love more of what’s beautiful in life. Intelligence, while often called sexy and attractive, is just one component of what makes one attracted to another. Many smart people become entrained in parts of society that tend to attract more smart people and then the laws of attraction kind of take over. In school there were many more competing factors and it was a different stage of life.

Like everything else, it depends on what you are attracted to. People that like shallow relationships do not really care about the IQ of their partner. However, if you prefer a deep relationship, you are sorta forced to choose someone in your ballpark. It only takes a minute to figure out that the slow person that is behind you in intellectual growth, is just going to fall further behind as time passes. The real danger in long term relationships is not that you are not on the same level, but that in a few years you no longer are.

Arthur Jensen, former psyc prof at Stanford, did cross cultural IQ studies for 14 years. I have never read the particular applicable study. But I have heard it quoted as finding a statistical correlation of IQ between husband and wife to be higher than between brother and sister. Further studies have found the comparisons to be at least equal. My late wife disputed this. She claimed to have married me for my looks, and some other mysterious redeeming characteristic. It damned sure wasn’t for my money at the time. I think even smart women just get desperate after a time.

I’ve read that, in a relationship, it is important to have similar intelligence, curiosity, and energy level. I’m definitely attracted to intelligent women but i may be weird that way. I know people, men, and women, who definitely go for looks. I know a guy, an engineer, who dated only blondes on Match.com. Some of his dates were as smart as a box of rocks… To me, hanging out with a dumb person, even nice and good-looking, is like hanging out with a baboon.
That is most likely. Why? Because your brain typically feels more relaxed when you are around people like you. This is also probably why cliques are a thing.
I don’t know whether they are attracted to smart people, but they definitely are not attracted to stupid people - at least not for long. They would get frustrated quite quickly.
YES!!! I need someone who understands what I am talking about. I need someone who is also open minded & not close minded. Intelligence is extremely sexy & rare to get or find.

An old human proverb applies here,”Birds of a feather flock together!” A genius interpretation of this proverb was given to me by my brother’s law partner and it reads this way, “Species of an ornithological plumage will congregate.” Which is a fancier way of saying the same thing.
